author: sky.cactus
content:
To clarify my current position.  I think core devs need a forcing function for regular updates.  Without it, we tend to drag our feet and delay rather than doing more frequent small updates.  See Berlin.

I don't like how the bomb works currently.  I would much rather see it as a function of time/block number rather than total difficulty.

I'm open to other solutions to forcing regular/frequent hard forks.  For me, a hard fork every 4-6 months feels like a good cadence.  Such a cadence will force us to improve the HF coordination process.

If it hurts, do more of it.

author: holiman
content: For me, the argument is not "we need the bomb to force regular updates". For me, the most compelling argument is "if someone wants to fork ethereum, it is not sufficient to just convince people to not upgrade to x.y". So, if there is a group who wants to fork ethereum to _not_ do 1559, or _not_ do the merge, then they have to actively gain sufficient credibility to make users _switch_ to use their (patched) software. So basically it removes the 'status quo fork' from the available options. We've lived with "da bomb" for years, and if we're chucking it out in a not-too-distant future anyway, I don't see why we need to do it now _now_

author: holiman
content: I agree that it's not technically challenging. I we (or anyone) wants to chuck it out, the change is simple, yes.

author: _shemnon
content: And this for me is a simple litmus test for the viability of any fork: can they find engineers who are willing to make the change, make a build, and get the software distributed?  That sounds easy _to us_ but it is a surprisingly high bar to clear for some fork organizers. Which to means it is working as intended. No zombie chains.

author: _shemnon
content: It's a technical mechanism for a social solution. My read of the angst over the bomb is how the effectiveness requires examining layer 8, 9, and 10 of the OSI model.
